programme.medium_synopsis: Dr Mark Lythgoe tells the untold story of medical imaging and why uncovering our inner selves changed the world.  In this programme he loos at the impact of the first X-rays and the double helix.
programme.long_synopsis:
Dr Mark Lythgoe, Director of the Centre for Advanced Biomedical Imaging at University College London, tells the untold story of medical imaging and why uncovering our inner selves changed the world.

The image of a ghostly skeletal hand, wearing an enormous wedding ring, shocked and fascinated the public when it hit the front page of newspapers around the world in January 1896. This was the first X-ray, taken by Wilhelm Roentgen of his wife Bertha. It sparked a worldwide trend for DIY X-ray kits, until the dangers emerged. Mark Lythgoe explains how seeing living skeletons revolutionised our view of the body.

One of the most iconic images produced by X-rays is that of the double helix of DNA, the stuff of life itself.  The famous twisting simplicity has captivated architects and designers ever since it was first discovered by Watson and Crick. Mark examines the cultural impact of this iconic image and assesses the implications its discovery has had on crime fiction.
